columns.text: In this exercise, we'll calculate the worth of a buyer's offer to purchase our company if he promises to pay $500,000 today and periodic payment of $150,000 per quarter for 25 quarters, increasing by 2% each quarter, and our needed EAR is 11%.

To solve the problem, we'll look into several following details:

| Particulars           |               |
|-----------------------|---------------|
| Initital payment      | $500,000        |
| Quarterly cashflows   | $150,000        |
| Quarterly growth rate | 2%            |
| EAR                   | 11%           |
| Period                | 25 (quarters) |

Since no interest rate is given, we'll start by computing the APR, or annual percentage rate. We'll use the target EAR, or effective annual rate, and the period of four to calculate the APR because we're computing an annual rate, and the periodic payment is made quarterly; hence, the compounding period in our calculation is four.

The APR is calculated by multiplying the nominal rate by the compounding period; however, since we're looking for the APR with a target EAR, we will consider the following modified AOR formula: 

$$ \begin{aligned}
APR &=m\left(\left(1+EAR\right)^{\dfrac{1}{m}}-1\right)
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$APR$, which means the annual percentage rate\
$EAR$, which represent the effective annual rate\
$m$, which indicated the compounding period

Let's now apply the APR formula from the previous step.

$$ \begin{aligned}
APR &=4\left(\left(1+0.11\right)^{\dfrac{1}{4}}-1\right)
\\[15pt]
&=4\left(0.026433327\right)
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{10.57\%}
\end{aligned}$$

As can be seen in our calculation, the annual percentage rate is 10.57%.

Next, considering the APR of 10.57% from the previous calculation, we must determine the present value of the $150,000 periodic quarterly payment for the next 25 quarters. An incremental pay rise of 2% every quarter is added to the recurrent payment.

We will utilize the present value of the growing annuity computation to find the present value of an annuity with a constant growth rate, as in the case of our exercise.

When calculating the present value of a growing annuity, the rate of increase of the annuity is considered on the factor multiplied by the periodic payment. Hence we will use the following formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{PV of Growing Annuity}  &=C\times\dfrac{1-\left(\dfrac{1+g}{1+r}\right)^t}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$PV$, which means present value\
$C$, which represent the cash amount\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$g$, which identifies the growth rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

Because the buyer likewise offers an initial payment of $500,000 right away. It is unnecessary to calculate its present value because it will remain the same as long as the payment is made today.

Finally, we'll determine the value of the buyer's offer by combining the present value of the recurring payment with a constant growth rate we calculated before and the initial payment of $500,000.

Let's now calculate the value of the buyer's offer.

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Offer's Value} &= \$3,391,755.83+\$500,000
\\[5pt]
&= \boxed{\bf\$3,891,755.83}
\end{aligned}$$

**As a result of our calculations, the buyer's bid to purchase our company is worth $3,891,755.83.**

To conclude, because the proposal includes a periodic payment factor, we calculated the present value of the annuity for 25 quarters. We combined it with the onset payment to determine the offer's value. Hence as a result of our calculation, the value of the buyer's offer is $3,891,755.83.
